title: Is the uncertainty principle only applicable to quantum mechanics? - Quora

response.answer_text: This question has two sides to it. Yes, the uncertainty principle only applies to quantum-mechanical objects. On classical objects, it has no effect whatsoever. However, this answer is somewhat misleading. Why? Because every object is quantum-mechanical — because the universe itself is quantum-mechanical. The uncertainty principle is not needed for any objects that can be described entirely by classical mechanics, but there are no such objects; even things on the scale of planets or galaxies must abide by the laws of quantum mechanics, because that is simply how the universe works. The laws of physics do not pick and choose their scales — they apply equally to all objects, regardless of nature. That would be like asking ‘Doesn’t gravity only apply to Newtonian objects, and not all objects?” But, I hear you ask, if this is true, then why don’t we see cars quantum tunneling through hills on our way to work? Or why don’t two buildings built too close together pull each other in via the Casimir effect? Well, the answer isn’t that the objects themselves aren’t affected by quantum mechanics. They have de Broglie wavelengths just like everything else, after all. The difference is that the effect of QM’s inherent randomness is incredibly minuscule on most scales larger than a molecule. Save for a few edge cases (such as neutron stars), most large objects can be modeled, to within a very tiny margin of error, using only Newton’s laws, and occasionally relativity. Even on the scale of the human body, our de Broglie wavelength is a few orders of magnitude smaller than the Planck length. So while it exists, its effects are so minuscule as to often be ignorable.
